results.title: Yackety Yack
results.brief_description: A classic Australian underground comedy in which a group of people fight over how to make the truly collective/revolutionary/existential movie. Original intentions get sidetracked but all attempts to set things straight result in yet another, but strangely similar, script. Cast includes: John Flaus, Peggy Cole.

results.title: Dalmas
results.brief_description: Dalmas was a key work in independent cinema of its time, and it’s still a fascinating cinema experience. Made on a collective basis mainly with members of the communal artistic performing group, The Tribe. Heavily influenced by hallucinations and the philosophy of the time, the film also impresses with its formal innovation.

results.title: The Game
results.creator_credit: ABC-TV (Australia), Michael Carson and Michael Jenkins
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Scales of Justice Series”.
The Game is a story of jealousy and conflict, personal and professional. Detective Sergeant Draffin and Miles are both from the same mould. Both are ruthlessly ambitious, both boast a reputation of being first class operators, and both are very confident of their ability. However, neither is used to sharing the limelight, and when Draffin is transferred to the Drug Squad, Miles’ home territory, the scene is set for a major confrontation. Rated: M

results.title: Chariots of fire
results.brief_description: Historical drama based on a true story of two members of Britain’s 1924 Olympic team, Harold Abrahams, a Jew running to prove himself in the face of the subtle hostility he found in his British environment, and Eric Liddell, a deeply religious man who refused to run on the Sabbath. Academy Award winner for Best Picture.

results.title: The World Is Watching
results.creator_credit: Peter Raymont, Harold Crooks, Jim Monro, Channel 4 Television Corporation, Great Britain, Ikon TV, Holland, Sveriges TV, Sweden, Investigative Productions Inc and TV Ontario
results.brief_description: Cameraman Don Holmberg and award-winning independent Canadian director, Peter Raymont, covered peace talks in Nicaragua, November 1987. What they saw, and what was reported on television networks in the US and Europe was quite different.

results.title: [Queen who returned Compilation]
results.creator_credit: H. Rodney Power, David Swift and State Film Centre of Victoria
results.brief_description: Features three films of Royal visits between 1954 and 1963. 1.”Royal Visit to Melbourne” - Her Majesty Queen Elizabeth and His Royal Highness the Duke of Edinburgh. 2.”Queen who Returned” - Queen Elizabeth, the Queen Mother, visits Victoria. 3.”Royal Visit” - Queen Elizabeth and the Duke on tour in Victoria.

results.title: Beyond sorrow beyond pain
results.brief_description: An emotionally moving re-enactment of the rehabilitation of a car accident victim who is blind and severely brain damaged. His girl friend is determined he should be rehabilitated with dignity and devotes years of her life to this end. Finally she is exhausted and must reconsider her position.

results.title: On borrowed time: the potter farm plan in action
results.brief_description: An eight part series which acts as a practical guide to farming with nature rather than against it and of realising the sustainability of the land, winning the war against soil degradation and maintaining productivity. Examines planning farm layout, water access and management, pasture and crop production, planting natural vegetation, fencing and siting of farms. Narrated by Neil Inall.

results.title: The Harp in the South
results.brief_description: Television dramatisation of Ruth Park’s novel following the life and times of a poor Irish Australian family in the aftermath of World War II. This is the poignant saga of the poverty-stricken Darcys of number 12 1/2 Plymouth Street in Surrey Hills - a Sydney slum with its complement of gangs, brothels and sly grog shops.

results.title: Jack Hibberd
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Australian playwrights speak”.
An interview with Australian playwright Jack Hibberd by Paul McGillick. Jack Hibberd’s plays have been characterised by great comic invention and an exploration of theatrical forms.
